Idleness. 
     931. To relieve the young from healthful labor is the worst possible course a parent can pursue. Their life is then aimless, the mind and hands  unoccupied, the imagination active, and left free to indulge in thoughts that are not pure and healthful. In this condition they are inclined to indulge still more freely in that vice which is the foundation of all their complaints. . . . Some mothers with their own hands open the door and virtually invite the  devil in, by permitting their children to remain in  idleness.-- S. A., p. 58.
